newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Spate of mishaps costs Taiwan oil giant US$40 mln.
newsitem.headline: Spate of mishaps costs Taiwan oil giant US$40 mln.

text.p: Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp said on Tuesday that compensation arising from a spate of oil leaks and fires would cost it more than T$1.1 billion ($40 million).
"We have reached agreements...to pay over T$1.1 billion in various kinds of compensation packages," Chinese Petroleum Vice President Fang Yi-shan told Reuters by telephone.
Residents' cars, buildings and boats that had been damaged or fouled by an August 9 oil leak and a later spill on land will be compensated for their clean-up costs, Fang said.
The payout also includes T$100 million to be added to an existing T$1.5 billion area development fund for residents near its No.5 naphtha cracking plant where the land leak occurred.
The series of accidents in August also included two costly fires, one of which halted production from a natural gas well.
Chinese Petroleum's insurer Chung Kuo Insurance Co Ltd is expected to pick up some of the losses.
